title: Does everyone have a different perception of reality? - Quora

response.answer_text: Absolutely! Perception is specific to every observer, what makes each observation subjective. 2 Observers might agree or disagree in some aspects of observed results - the stronger they will agree with eachother, the closer they get to the objective state of reality. Let’s take a human, a bat, a rattlesnake (with infrared vision) and a small insect, then let them observe some determined process. Compare the way, in which this process is perceived by all observervers. How do you think, would a rattlesnake “understand” reality perceived by echolocation of a bat. And better, if I won’t mention about the perception of a fruitfly or some other coakroach. I can’t even imagine how things look like for a bug. It’s like another reality within bigger reality (science calls this fractal-like). And yet, each kind of living creature need to be cosidered in physics, as a potential observer, capable to process information, collected by sensing his local environment… And now here’s my question: how does mainstream science deal with such defined problem? Because now comes the funny part. Every observer has the ability, to affect the ongoing process in a definitive and objective way. Change induced by any observer, will affect in some way the reality, as it is perceivwed by all other creatures in the local environment. Change induced by observers, can be traced in the timeline of events, which were observed and recorded some time earlier… If any observer decides to affect in some way an ongoing process, it will cause a definitive change in observed reality, which can’t be never fully un-done. You could possibly take a gun and kill the rattlesnake and then stomp on the insect just by accident. If any of this really happens, it will become an objective fact for every other observer. And now comes the great blasphemy - as observers can’t possibly be aware of all cause/effect relations for a timeline with multiple events. Can anyone be absolutely sure, tha the death of insect, can’t be in any way related to a bullet inside the reptile’s head? Maybe, if he wouldn’t shoot the snake, he wouldn’t then accidentaly stomp on the insect… And in such case, is it even possible, to learn about the definitive truth about the objective state of reality? Somehow I can’t see here too much space for actual determinism

It is likely. To a Christian, reality is different than to a Hindu, Buddhist or Jain. Same thing I can say about Islam or even Judaism. To a Christian, Christ was the ONLY son of God, but for a Hindu every one of us is a son of God and each one of us is a part of universal reality. To a Christian, God sent his only son, but Hindus believe there were sages sent to guide the mankind and Buddha was one of them. Buddhists also believe that there were Buddhas before Gautama Buddha and there will be Buddhas after him. Even within Buddhism, perception of reality had been different within different sects. After Buddha’s parinirvana, his words were carefully dissected and analyzed. Buddha gave a broad explanation of suffering, but Vibhashika philosophers gave a long list of elements of suffering and then try to explain how these elements are perceived by our mind and then they explained how to end suffering. sautrantika philosophers later stated that the elements which are perceived by our mind are different than those which are produced at the core level. So not all elements are perceived by our mind. Then around 150AD, greatest Buddhist scholar Nagarjuna stated that the elements of suffering are constantly changing and they are not absolute elements and they are dependent on other elements and therefore our perception is in constant flux. So final results can be completely misleading if we think that elements do not change. He stated his philosophy is based on Buddha’s statements that everything constantly changes. This Sunyata philosophy led to other philosophies later. One of the philosophy is Ksanika (momentary) philosophy. Ksanka philosophers started thinking about how these momentary pulses change and st what rate, and whether they affect time and space. The conclusion was that they affect time and space and that the motion is digital and not analog . To a Muslim, Mohammad was the last prophet, but soon after the death of Mohammad, new sects arose and now Islam has several sects in spite of the fact that Sunnis keep on enforcing that Quran is the word of God and Muhammad is the last prophet. Bahais, Shia, Bohras, Khojas and many other sects have arisen. So the perception of reality has changed.

Yes, they have to. Each individual is shaped by the biological, psychological, sociological domain in which their cognition is launched from. Because there are differences in all of those domains for all things, one can only be shaped the way that they are shaped. You can have identical twins, both eating the same thing for lunch, sitting side by side in sleds, sledding down the mountain at the exact same time.. one of them might have the perception that they are superman flying, their endorphins are high they feel like they are on top of the world, the other, might think, omg i’m going to hit a tree and have my brains smashed out, their adrenlin and fear are up and they are deeply fearful and afraid. So yes, each has a different perception of the same physical reality. This function or feature extends to all components of emerged cognition, that is, it applies to belief and political ideations in the same way. Typically there will be a bell curve distribution of any thoughts or systems that emerge from any given population.

It is easy to say yes but that is not clear. The point is that the mind builds our reality by observing a consistent external environment. Other people obeserve the same reality and we can agree on a common basis evern though we don’t know how they see it. Interactions with people and the world all work as we anticipate they should. So the basis for undertanding is perfect reasonable , but the underlying perceptions are potentially unique to all. Take colour for example this does not enter the eyes as say… red , it simply triggers a red cone which sends spikes of electro-chemical activity into te brain - it is the brain that creates the discriminant we call colour and we call this internal perception a quale (plural qualia). We you see in your mind may well be unique to you but it is always consistent red objects appear as your red and similar the red objects in others appears as their red so the result is consistent even if (and we cannot prove one way or the other) it is always different for everyone else. See: Qualia (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy)

Does everyone have a different perception of reality ?  If we look at it from the quantum perspective, in fact everyone build his own personal reality when observing it through his five senses. In quantum mechanics "realism" means "notion that physical systems possess complete sets of definite values for various parameters prior to, and independent of, measurement »[1] Most theoremes and experiments falsify and rule out the existence of reality as we imagine it.[2]  When coming back to newtonian world we can consider that the perception of reality is a kind of collective construction with groups of men and women sharing similar beliefs and different moments in time. Questions as free will, morals, our relationships with nature, animals and other human beings are deeply influenced by our peers.  This said our personal understanding is based on our last recall of memories. Each time a souvenir arises in our mind he is stored back in a new version which becomes our reality. The more we are exposed to a certain reality, the stronger our convinctions about its nature. “Often we don’t realize that our attitude toward something has been influenced by the number of times we have been exposed to it in the past.” — Robert B. Cialdini Footnotes[1] Leggett inequality - Wikipedia[2] Bell's theorem - Wikipedia

Yes, and no. Reality is the most complex system that we can possibly imagine. It is full of paradoxes. For example, everybody has about the same DNA, so this means that we perceive Reality in basically the same way. Colors, shapes, speed, sounds, food, flavor, odors, textures, and street traffic signs are basically the same for everybody. However — we obviously differ according to Taste (Style). Some people love spicy food, and others cannot tolerate it. Some people love fast cars, and others cannot abide them. Some people love opera, while others will not sit still for it. Some people love modern Art, while others mock it. And so on. Further, we obviously differ according to Economic Class. Some people are rich, and perceive the world from the perspective of the rich — wanting more and wanting to keep what they have, and to pay fewer taxes. Other people are middle class, and perceive the world through those eyes. Everybody should work. Everybody should pay taxes. Everybody should rise in education as far as possible. Everybody should take care of his or her own family. Everybody should obey the law, or submit to prison terms. Everybody should carefully guard the health of their families. Other people are poor, and perceive the world through the eyes of poverty. Where is my next meal going to come from? How can I understand the modern world and the modern economy, which gets more complex every day? How can I escape the cycle of poverty? Why do drugs and alcohol seem to be viable solutions for my situation? Where is the welfare office? This brief summary only scratches the surface, but we can rightly conclude — people share many important perspectives — and people differ sharply among many important perspectives. It’s not an Either/Or proposition.

Here’s the interesting thing about the question. Folk wisdom wants us to believe two things that are actually quite contradictory: I am an individual. I am different, in fact, completely unique.We all have accurate— and therefore similar— perceptions of the one true reality. Anyone who doesn’t, is delusional or a deviant.This would imply that perceptions are ONLY about the world, and not at all dependent on something about the self, the perceiver. But we know that every perceiver has a somewhat or very different position, exposure to different regions of our shared reality, and more than that, different interests and mental capacities for making sense of things. The meanings of “similar” and “different” are not in any way opposites— things can be both similar and different at the same time. It’s just a matter of degree, and of what we choose to emphasize in order to make a particular point or get a particular job done while coordinating with others. When and where do you focus on the differences, and on the similarities?

Yes, our perception of reality is completely egocentric, subjective, we can consider reality as a projection of our own conscious, seeing our own inner qualities reflected back to us from a “white screen”. We can look at it in a different way as well, since perception is based on the similarity of qualities, frequencies between the observer and observed - like in the case of a radio receiver - we can't detect anything else from a presumed “outside reality” but what we already have matching templates, memories with. Thus I can only sense on the “outside” what's in the “inside”. As a result of we want to change the world we see, we need to change the qualities, abilities of movie projector, changing ourselves. Change The Movie Of Your Life To A Better One | Laitman.com Staring Into The Mirror | Laitman.com

Yes, everyone’s perception is from a point in space where their five senses expand outward to gather information of the world around them. If the person’s mind is full of non-sense, then their view may be wrong or distorted a bit. If their view is correct, they still must constantly be questioning everything in order to not be led astray from what is truth. Whatever anyone’s perception is, they must search out knowledge. Knowledge in spiritual terms is truth and wisdom. We must gather our information from what is seen and what is unseen. This is why we should observe the world around us (that which is seen) and question everything. And then we should go within ourselves, because this is where the unseen world is. Meditation can help with this part of the journey. We do this so when everything is said and done. We discover the truth without anyone’s help. That is if we always question everything and contemplate those results.

The only thing we can say with certainty is that we believe so, but since it is not possible to exactly know each person’s perception of reality and make comparison objectively, we can only assume everyone does. However what I find so interesting is people often ask this type of question that people may answer in so many different ways even it looks like a yes-or-no, i.e. close-ended, question. Perhaps it is easy to find out the answer to this question by just posting whatever topics and ask people what/her they feel/see/think about it. By looking at the number of variations, one will be able to know how many different ways people are able to see the exactly the same thing.

Hey Eisop Naturally, since we're all different finely tuned individual perceptions IN reality, we have different perceptions OF reality. I wonder if you're asking if we all have a different understanding of what reality actually is. My experience of this one reality is based on what I believe is true. I can only perceive what I conceive in my awareness. This will be based on what I've been taught by my family, tribe and nation. Accepting their truth of what reality can be and cannot be, I cannot see another's ……unless, by a bold step in consciousness, I transform my beliefs and conceive and THEN perceive something else. Thereby, I can get a new understanding of what reality can be. Hopefully, I will recognise how reality bends to any conception I hold true, and testing this, perceive beyond the inevitable limits of what I was taught. Hope that's helpful All the best

I would agree that we all have a different perception of reality due to our unique genetic heritage and environment we were raised in. Our perception is subjective. I also know that there is an objective reality that is concealed from us. The wisdom called Kabbalah is the science of the correct perception of true reality: what it is and how it is manifested. Tony Kosinec give the kabbalistic perception of reality.

Because everyone is an individual, i.e., no two persons are exactly alike, not even identical twins, everyone’s perception of reality will be different, though it may be similar to people who have a similar “material reality,” i.e., live in the same town, go to the same school, have a similar-looking home, etc. If a group of people come from the same culture, their cultural outlook about certain things will be very similar but not exactly alike. If there is a national dance, such as the Irish jig, not everyone will perform it exactly the same way because some people have longer legs & can dance faster, some drank too much Irish whiskey & can’t dance much at all, etc. You get the idea. I know you were looking for a philosophical answer to this question so here it is: as I explained above with material issues, the same goes with thought processes in the mind. We might all start with same idea fixed in our minds, but our subconscious preferences/idiosyncrasies about the idea, good/bad memories, people we associate with it, & miscellaneous other things come creeping into the idea, making it uniquely OUR idea now & what we think of it. That is what makes our reality of the idea different from anyone else’s reality of the idea. I hope my demonstrations have helped you.

Eery human and living beinghas a different perception of physical life and telepathically, enmass, it is shared among all and agreed to look the same enmass for all. Perception, as you know, is illusion and personal reality. It is camouflaged and transformation of your inner reality. Inner reality is created by your deep thoughts, beliefs, feelings, desires, emotions and expectations and there is no other way. You have to be careful each moment of your life consciously wht you think and believe because that will be your reality you want to physically experience.

Reality……….. as we perceive it to be is reallusion (illusion portrayed as reality). It is what we are surrounded with and what we perceive and interact with our senses and body. People interact with the reallusion around them with differing mind-sets unique to each one. I am not equal to you nor am I higher or lower than you. I am simply what I am and you are what you are! The uniqueness of mind-sets depends on the degree and nature of exposure to awareness and knowledge garnered from childhood to adulthood which differs from person to person. In this context the possibility of entertaining varied perceptions of reallusion is possible.

If you had a group of people standing in a circle and inside the circle were four people all doing different magic tricks, everyone’s perspective would be different than the others on the outside of the circle. That changes perception of what was going on. Experiences, learnered reactions, eduacation, religious beliefs, clear vision, the person’s mental stability… all factors. Back in the day, people who witnessed a crime through wavey glass were not allowed to testify.

Does everyone have a different perception of reality? At some levels, consequential or inconsequential, yes. Think of the variety of taste buds, tactile sensitivity ranges from day to day and person to person… This does not mean we cannot have agreement on issues of coherence. It means to form a better picture of reality we would do well to hear and value the expressed perceptions of others.

No, because although reality only exists within an understanding as the remembered form and meaning of experiences, it will be the same for all those people of the same race sharing the same kind of lives in the same location with the same beliefs about right and wrong. And is how society comes into being as a shared understanding. ( see A simple definition of Community(Society) by P Atkinson (11-Mar-19) )

Intellectually, that is totally impossible to know. Spiritually, what is clear, is that each individual is unique, even though they may form a “ group consciousness” (herd instinct), where they “ think” they have the same perception. Even the top of the intellectual tree (scientists) have to rely on peer review (group rules). This applies across the board.

Yes, everyone’s perception of reality differs from everyone else’s. Each person’s perception is their individual reality because perception is reality. It’s as simple as that. The entirety of the universe is subsumed in your perception of it, which obviously includes every other person as well as their individual realities of which you are a part too. Their you is not your you and your they is not their they but you are a component of their reality. We are all solipsists in superposition.

Yes and no. We are individuals who see life based on our own perspective. Which in turn is based on our experiences and our thoughts of those experiences. So, from that point of view, we are all different. However, we are also alike because we follow similar patterns and routines of life. Of course, there are always exceptions, but humans usually operate in the day time and sleep at night. We are best when we have activities that interest us. We go to work, raise a family, and obey the laws of the land. Those who don’t get into trouble.

Hell yeah! There are things like I smack your face. Does it hurt? well.., yes! Universal. Now you ask… is this dish spicy hot? Well may be not for you. No idea for someone else. Reality of hot is different. Yes. Now multiply that with wow … I don’t know… every moment of their life that has shaped their view of the world.

I've said this always 20 times but your new. We all suffer from dilusions. If we didn't then we would never face frustration and anger. Frustration and anger comes from expectations. Expect nothing ever and you will be much happier. Genuinely hope for all. The expectations that don't turn out to be true are where our perceptions change. You expect it to rain tomorrow and I dont and one of us is delusional. One of us is not in tune with what reality is only on that disagreement. How many disagreements do you think the human race have a day?

What kind of reality are we talking about? We all perceive a tree as a concept representing a tree, a chair as a chair and so on. Objects are easily perceived has having the same reality for every human being. The perception of the qualities of an object depends on a certain point of view : if you see a table in full daylight and somebody else sees it in the darkness, the perception of its color will be different but it will still be a table.

More or less. EG.a blind person, a deaf person. Some people thinks that reality stops with what our senses tells us - but reality includes thoughts and feelings too. They may appear very different in different persons

We all tend towards variables on a general theme with regard to our own perceptual interpretation of collective and sensory data. The primary variables being composed of tangible, intangible and creative perceptions in reality, based upon imposed, environmental and personal circumstances defined by experiences and degree of maturity at any given time frame. There to all data would also be filtered through our own unique system of fundamental beliefs. To suggest that no two perceptions of reality despite similarities would be exactly the same would be considered a valid theory.

Yes, everyone has a different perception of reality. The reason why it doesn’t seem like that is because one’s perception is heavily influenced by other people’s perception, so it seems that everyone perceives the same way.

Everybody has a different perception of that reality around because of different levels of personal consciousness… imagine some group of people with fully developed consciousness as ONE with it… they have that same perception of Reality the Absolute… all the best.

Your earthly reality exists as your personalized, individualized perceptions of your earthly reality unless you do not permit perceptions, impressions, opinions, basically guesses, to control, define, determine your earthly reality. There is so much more to this tell….I have written a book, How Does Man Ccome to Know….should be available on Amazon by the end of 2019.

Technically it is very arguably the case, but in practice the overlap is very large and that is all that is required for general living and practicalities. When a sufficiently large discrepancy is found, eg red-green colour blindness, this is dealt with by not allowing such persons to become pilots, artists, electricians, etc.
True!

Probably slightly different (think of a near-sighted man vs a far-sighted man) — but they both must see the same reality to a large degree because they both survive in it. That's the final test of your perceptions.

Since humans share acommonality culturally etc, there are many similar perceptions ,but reality is far different than what we have bought into. The emperical world is shared more ea Sily because humans have not developed their three brain capacity

The experience of reality is a construction drawn upon the individual’s unique non-conscious learned understanding dependent upon their perspective of self and non-self. The degree to which one integrates their perception with an interpretation of what is perceived to be another’s perception, their experience of reality is enhanced and expanded. However, this virtual reality will never perfectly correspond to actual reality.
Yes and no, depending upon the context. Every one sees a circle as a circle. Every one sees a situation or a person differently. There might be some overlaps but there could be some
Perceptions can be different but that doesn't mean everyone has a different perception. Most likely the perception depends on life experiences
Insofar as people are part of reality, then the answer is yes, because no one knows the real you and vice versa. All we have are opinions of each other.

Ofcorse. Reality is different because you’re different. But……..the two poles of a magnet are different and still they constitute a magnetic field, selling and buying are different and still they are one process, front and back are different, but they go together. There is no back without a front so…. This is called the duality off existence, ying and yang.
Yes, that would have to be. Just standing in a different location will give you a different perspective and your body differences, as minute as they might be, will give you different perceptions.
Of the 7.6 billion humans some will have the same perception of reality using mathematical probability, but most will have a different perception from a small degree to an extreme.

Imagine a large, faceted jewel, with a thousand facets. Each facet has a different view of the very same center. The view through each facet gives a different perception of the same reality. Each view is different, but also shows truth.
Probably, but it does not matter. What is important is to realize truth existed before us, while we are alive and after we are gone. Know and seek truth.

It is true that when I see an apple a particular pattern of neurons fires in my brain which is not the same pattern that fires in your brain. However, I will announce, “That’s an apple,” so language links the two patterns and creates a uniform reality.

Perception, reality and people Perception is by definition individual subjective. We use language and other technologies to come to a consensus of what reality is/means. As scientists we put forth models of what we think it might be, which we try to falsify with experiments.
Yes cause if it was Not we would all be the sameasfaras opinionlevels vs prespetion and no longer be individualistic.but if this is in reference to inautomate. Objects like chairs.etc..the yes
Yes. In literature, this has been referred to as private consciousness. I highly recommend this book: A very short introduction to consciousness.

Very good question. We do not perceive the reality because we have no ability to. What we perceive is the illusionary world of images, sounds, feelings etc. through our sensory nervous system of limited ability. However, we have a mechanism inbuilt in us which, once triggered, gives us a light to see the truth and reality. Try Sahaja Yoga, it is always free. Good luck
Yes, everybody knows this don’t we. We are each of us in a different position in spacetime, so yes, our perception is different. The same logic applies to the non-physical realms.
A2A Yes. Perception is individually tailored according to the person's karma and desires. Each is the centre of the scene they experience.

Greetings Eisop, there are 4 Realities or perceptions of Reality: 1- the one that we think (which is unreal) 2- the one others think (which is subjective) 3- the one that we feel(which is conditional) 4- the one that exists with or without our approval and/or knowledge (which is The Reality) In Peace and Friendship, Pierre
Big question, lot of facets…but yes, the answer is yes.
Good question,most probably ,yes.
Yep.
Yes
